topics.body: The reason why things in general get popular is because the word gets spread about them, And Works that are considered to be unique get this with the most force. (It's still possible for works that are good but not unique to get mainstream recognition, But It's a lot harder.)

topics.body:
"@trashboat":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/54a898ed63687228d06c0200#post_54a898ed63687228d06c0200
And that's the problem; while it's possible for non-unique anime or such to become popular there's the problem of it already being done preventing large scale popularity.  Basically what I mean by this is that it's entirely possible for say boku no hero academia to become as popular as people are claiming it will be the possibility of it becoming so is extremely small.

My money is on we're going to have a 5-10 year timeframe until the next big thing and after that series ends another 5-10 year timeframe until the big thing after that for the simple fact that there's too much competition for some singular franchise to pull ahead.

"@trashboat":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/54a899d7636872572d561200#post_54a899d7636872572d561200
[bq="trashboat"]The reason why things in general get popular is because the word gets spread about them, And Works that are considered to be unique get this with the most force. (It's still possible for works that are good but not unique to get mainstream recognition, But It's a lot harder.)[/bq]
Suuuuuurrreeeeee and Call of Duty and the Michael Bay Transformers movies are popular totally because it's a amazing franchise.

Sarcasm aside marketing and advertisment has a huge impact on popularity.  Look at Destiny; Bungie literally blew most of the budget on advertisment and as a result the game sold like hot cakes even though the game is average/subpar.

Don't like being that guy but

"@QuasarNova":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/54a20c066368725c71dd0400#post_54a20c066368725c71dd0400
[bq="QuasarNova"]I do agree with uc9, but I'm fixing his stuff:

It's not shonen being overdone, it's the +action adventure genre+ that has gotten to a point there's few new things you can do with it.

My Hero Academia nowhistanding.

However, here's more a case on the main readers from Japan (We're talking about a ver centric country here), and there's a broader market of people who prefer reading adventure and slice of life, those tend to stick a little more than say: romantic comedies or horror.

There are plenty of underrated mangas and anime, and that always happens in any media (videogames, movies, books).[/bq]

That was my booty call!

topics.body:
"@QuasarNova":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/54a89c4e6368727c5a6e0400#post_54a89c4e6368727c5a6e0400
The thing is though that if it were true then as soon as Naruto ended then something should have filled the gap, but the thing is though nothing really has filled the gap and nothing seems to be stepping up to the plate.

People keep going "ermagod boku no hero academia is going to be bigger than naruto!"  Sure it's popular and I totally admit that it has a large viewership, but it's the 42nd most popular manga and it seems to be stuck there.
